mn84:21.3: Just as one might set upright what had been overturned, or reveal what had been hidden, or show the way to one who was lost, or bring a lamp into the darkness so that one with eyes might see what is there—
mn84:21.4: Master Kaccāna has made the Dharma clear in many ways.
mn84:21.5: I go for refuge to Master Kaccāna, to the Dharma, and to the mendicant Saṅgha.
mn84:21.6: From this day forth, may Master Kaccāna remember me as a lay follower who has gone for refuge for life.”
mn84:21.7: “Great King, don’t go for refuge to me.
mn84:21.8: You should go for refuge to that same Blessed One to whom I have gone for refuge.”
mn84:21.9: “But where is that Blessed One now staying, the perfected one, the fully awakened Buddha?”
mn84:21.10: “Great King, the Buddha has already become fully extinguished.”
mn84:21.11: “Master Kaccāna, if I heard that the Buddha was within ten leagues, or twenty, or even up to a hundred leagues away, I’d go a hundred leagues to see him.
mn84:21.14: But since the Buddha has become fully extinguished, I go for refuge to that fully extinguished Buddha, to the teaching, and to the Saṅgha.
mn84:21.15: From this day forth, may Master Kaccāna remember me as a lay follower who has gone for refuge for life.”
